Fig 10 Research Paper Steam activation significantly promotes the CO oxidation performance of Pt/CeZrO2 catalyst: Enhancement effect and mechanism Jingwei Li Writing – original draft Investigation Formal analysis a 1 Zhao Liu Writing – original draft Methodology Investigation b 1 Kaijie Liu Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft Funding acquisition a b ⁎ Xin Shen Investigation b Xiaohui Chen Investigation b Yangfei Fang Investigation b Yibo Zhang Supervision Resources Project administration Funding acquisition b ⁎ Xiangguang Yang Supervision Resources b a Engineering Research Center of Coal-based Ecological Carbon Sequestration Technology of the Ministry of Education, Shanxi Datong University, Datong 037009, China Engineering Research Center of Coal-based Ecological Carbon Sequestration Technology of the Ministry of Education Shanxi Datong University Datong 037009 China aEngineering Research Center of Coal-based Ecological Carbon Sequestration Technology of the Ministry of Education, Shanxi Datong University, Datong 037009, China b Ganjiang Innovation Academy, Chinese Academy of Sciences, No.1, Science Academy Road, Ganzhou 341000, China Ganjiang Innovation Academy Chinese Academy of Sciences No.1, Science Academy Road Ganzhou 341000 China bGanjiang Innovation Academy, Chinese Academy of Sciences, No.1, Science Academy Road, Ganzhou 341000, China ⁎ Corresponding authors at: Ganjiang Innovation Academy, Chinese Academy of Sciences, No.1, Science Academy Road, Ganzhou 341000, Jiangxi, PR China. Ganjiang Innovation Academy, Chinese Academy of Sciences No.1, Science Academy Road Ganzhou Jiangxi 341000 PR China 1 These authors contributed equally to this work. CO oxidation reaction has important industrial significance in controlling automotive exhaust emissions, however, the effect of steam on the activity of ceria-zirconia solid solutions supported catalyst is still unclear. In this study, ceria-zirconia solid solutions were prepared by the traditional co-precipitation method (CZO) and the novel ammonium carbonate etching method (CZOe). After loading 1 wt% Pt, the synthesized Pt/CZOe and Pt/CZO catalysts were characterized comprehensively by XRD, HAADF-STEM, XPS, DRIFTS, and Raman spectroscopy, the results suggested that the Pt species were uniformly dispersed as Pt2+ single sites. Both Pt/CZOe and Pt/CZO catalysts could be activated under wet conditions and showed improved CO oxidation activity compared to dry conditions, especially the CO complete conversion temperature (T100) of Pt/CZOe decreased by 100 °C. Furthermore, the enhancement mechanism of steam on the catalysts has been deeply studied using in-situ CO DRIFTS spectra analysis and 18O isotope labeling experiments, which indicated that H2O molecules were adsorbed and dissociated on the surface of the catalysts, forming terminal Ce-OH bonds that facilitated the reaction rate. The Pt/CZOe catalyst showed a remarkable enhancement of low-temperature CO oxidation activity under wet conditions compared to the Pt/CZO catalyst due to the outstanding porosity which facilitates the adsorption of H2O molecules. In the H2 18O-involved experiments, the formation of C18O2 and C18O16O and the appearance of the C18O-Pt2+ band demonstrated that H2O molecules participated in the reaction directly as reactants, the CO bond of CO molecules adsorbed on Pt could be broken and replaced by hydroxyl oxygen of adjacent Ce-OH. The present work revealed the enhancement effect and mechanism of steam on the CO oxidation performance of ceria-zirconia solid solutions supported catalyst, and the research methods and results in this work have important reference significance for the activation research of other catalysts. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Ceria-zirconia solid solutions Steam Pt Carbon monoxide 18O isotope labeling Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The CO oxidation reaction is an essential primary reaction in automotive exhaust catalytic conversion. It has been widely studied since the 1970s due to its fundamental characteristics and technical relevance to emission control regulations [1,2]. CO oxidation reaction requires the support of catalysts with both high activity and thermal stability [3]. With the improvement of internal combustion engine efficiency, more advanced low-cost batteries will further help increase the frequency of internal combustion engine opening and closing, thereby reducing the heat obtained by the rear-end catalytic reactions [4,5]. Therefore, it is necessary to investigate the performance of catalysts at low temperatures to meet the high standards of clean emissions. Water is one of the most common substances worldwide and plays a vital role in catalysis. Catalyst treatment through steam reforming or other water-related methods is simple and feasible. This low-cost treatment has been shown to enhance catalyst performance significantly [1]. Researchers found that the presence of water vapor can increase the rate of CO oxidation of gold catalysts by more than two orders of magnitude [6,7]. Wang et al. prepared Pt1/CeO2 by atomic layer deposition (ALD) for CO oxidation and found that co-feeding water vapor into the reaction gas can form additional Ce-OH bonds on the catalyst surface, significantly enhancing catalytic activity [8]. However, the presence of water can sometimes have the opposite effect, such as competing for active sites and reducing the catalytic rate [9]. Considering the existence of water vapor in automobile exhaust [10], it is necessary to study the impact of water vapor on catalytic activity. In our study, we investigated the promoting effect of water vapor on the activity of CO oxidation. We used ceria-zirconia solid solutions (CeO2-ZrO2) prepared by the co-precipitation method and ammonium carbonate etching method as supports and then loaded 1 wt% Pt by the initial wetness impregnation method. We tested the CO oxidation activity of these two catalysts under dry and wet conditions. Compared to dry conditions, both catalysts showed improved CO oxidation activity after co-feeding 2.5 kPa water vapor. In particular, the catalyst using CeO2-ZrO2 prepared by ammonium carbonate etching method as support exhibited excellent low-temperature CO oxidation activity with a T100 decrease from 190 °C to 90 °C. Subsequently, the catalyst was further characterized to explore the mechanism of water vapor activation of the catalyst. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst preparation Based on the principle that Zr4+ ions can easily form [Zr(CO3)4]4− complexes with CO3 2− under alkaline conditions, while Ce3+ ions are hardly coordinated by CO3 2− under such conditions, we prepared ceria-zirconia solid solutions with excellent thermal stability by a novel ammonium carbonate etching method. 2.3158 g Ce(NO3)3·6H2O (99.99 %, Adamas), 0.8222 g ZrO(NO3)2 (99 %, Macklin) (molar ratio of Ce to Zr was 6:4) and 30 mL deionized water were mixed and stirred until the solution was clear and colorless. Add 2.5 mL concentrated ammonia solution (25–28 %, Greagent) to the beaker containing 7.5 mL deionized water, and stir well. The diluted ammonia solution was added dropwise to the cerium-zirconium ion mixture under stirring for about 20 min, and the suspension was stirred for 30 min after the dropwise addition. Subsequently, 15 mL (NH4)2CO3 solution consisting of 0.72 g (NH4)2CO3 (AR, Macklin) was added to the cerium-zirconium hydroxide suspension, stirred for 30 min and left for 12 h to complete the ammonium carbonate etching step. The resulting mixture was centrifuged, washed twice with deionized water and anhydrous ethanol, and dried in an oven at 80 °C for 8 h. The resulting solid sample was ground into powder and calcined in air at 500 °C for 4 h using a muffle furnace with a heating rate of 2 °C/min to obtain the products named CZOe. For comparison, the products prepared without the ammonium carbonate etching step were noted as CZO. The catalysts were prepared by the initial wetness impregnation method, with the following specific steps: take an appropriate mass of CZOe or CZO as the support, and platinum nitrate aqueous solution (Pt(NO3)2, 18.02 wt% Pt, Macklin) was diluted by deionized water and added to the supports. The specific volume of the platinum nitrate solution depends on the total pore volume of the corresponding mass of CZOe or CZO, which was obtained by N2 adsorption and desorption testing. The resulting mixture was further ultrasonically treated for 30 min and subsequently dried in an oven at 80 °C for 8 h. After drying, the mixture was placed in a muffle furnace and calcined at 400 °C for 2 h with a ramp of 2 °C/min under static air to obtain the Pt/CZOe and Pt/CZO catalysts, in which the loading of Pt was 1 wt%. The accurate composition of Pt/CZOe and Pt/CZO was analyzed by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscope (ICP-OES), as shown in Table S1. It can be seen from Table S1 that the Ce to Zr ratio value of Pt/CZOe is higher than Pt/CZO, indicating the etching effect of carbonate on zirconium [11]. 2.2 Catalytic activity tests For the CO catalytic oxidation activity tests, 20 mg of catalyst was homogenously mixed with 180 mg of quartz sand (40–60 mesh), then placed in a quartz tube with an inner diameter of 6 mm and loaded in a fixed bed reactor. The composition of the experimental reaction gas was 0.5% vol. CO, 10% vol. O2, in an Ar balance, the gas flow rate is 50 mL/min, and the total space velocity is 150,000 mL·g−1·h−1. For the catalytic oxidation of CO under wet conditions, water vapor was introduced by passing the reaction gas through a wash bottle containing deionized water at a temperature of 20 °C corresponding to a water vapor pressure of 2.5 kPa. The composition of the generated gas after the reaction was detected by an online gas chromatography GC2060 (Shanghai Ruimin Instrument Co., Ltd.). 2.3 Characterization X-ray diffraction analysis (XRD) : The XRD measurements were conducted by Rigaku Smartlab SE instrument (Japan) with a Cu Kα excitation light source. The tube voltage and tube current of this equipment in the tests were 40 kV and 30 mA, respectively. The specific scanning range was 20 to 80°, the step size was 0.02°, and the scanning rate was 2°/min. Nitrogen adsorption-desorption : The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were analyzed at 77 K on a Builder Kubo1200 instrument (China). The specific surface areas (SBET) were calculated by the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) equation. The pore size distribution curves were calculated by the Barret-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. Single point total pore volume was determined at P/P0 = 0.99. Aberration-corrected High Angle Annular Dark Field Scanning Transmission Electron Microscopy (HAADF-STEM): The Aberration-corrected HAADF-STEM images and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) mapping were taken on a FEI Titan G2 60-300 instrument equipped with a Super-X EDS detector (America). Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM): The TEM images were taken on a FEI Talos F200S instrument (America) with a total voltage of 200 kV. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) : The surface element analysis of the catalysts was tested by Thermo Fisher Scientific K-Alpha instrument (America). The excitation source was Al Kα X-ray (hv=1486.6 eV), and the vacuum degree of the sample chamber was 2 × 10−5 Pa. The charge shift calibration was carried out by calibrating the C1s orbital binding energy of the contaminated carbon at 284.8 eV. Hydrogen Temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR): H2-TPR experiments were conducted by Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 instrument equipped with a TCD detector (America). 30 mg catalysts were pre-treated at 300 °C in 10 % O2/Ar for 1 h and cooled down to room temperature in pure Ar. Then the gas was switched to 10 % H2/Ar (30 ml/min), and the temperature was raised from room temperature to 700 °C with a ramp of 10 °C/min. Raman Spectroscopy: The Raman spectra of catalysts were analyzed using a Renishaw inVia confocal microscope system (England). Samples were illuminated through a 50x eyepiece using a 532 nm laser with an acquisition range of 200–1200 cm−1 and a resolution of 4 cm−1. The laser had a laser intensity of 10 %, an exposure time of 2 s, and a cumulative count of 5 times. Diffused Reflectance Infrared Fourier Transform Spectroscopy (DRIFTS) : CO DRIFTS spectra were collected by Nicolet iS50 instrument equipped with a Harrick diffuse cell and an MCT detector (America). Before testing, the catalysts were loaded in the sample cell and then heated at 300 °C for 30 min under the atmosphere of 20 % O2 (20 mL/min, N2 balanced), then the atmosphere was switched to pure Ar (20 mL/min) and heated at 300 °C for 15 min. Subsequently, the background spectrum was collected after the sample cell was cooled to 50 °C under an Ar atmosphere. In the process of CO adsorption, the gas flow was 5 % CO in an Ar balance, while during oxidative treatment, the gas flow was 10%O2 in an Ar balance, with a gas flow rate of 20 mL/min for both CO adsorption and oxidative treatment. During the test, the spectra were collected every minute, with a resolution of 4 cm−1 for 32 scans. In-situ CO DRIFTS measurements under wet conditions over Pt/CZOe and Pt/CZO were performed as follows: The catalysts were pretreated and cooled to 50 °C, and a background spectrum was collected. Then, the catalysts were purged with 2.5 % CO and 10 % O2 in an Ar balance (40 mL/min) for 15 min. After the dry reaction, 2.5 kPa water vapor was introduced into the gas flow by passing the reaction gas through a wash bottle containing deionized water at a temperature of 20 °C, and the catalysts were continued purged for another 15 min. Afterwards, CO was removed, and the gas flow was switched to 10 % O2 in an Ar balance (40 mL/min) with 2.5 kPa water vapor. During the test, the spectra were collected every minute, with a resolution of 4 cm−1 for 32 scans. Mass spectroscopy (MS): The experiment steps of 18O isotope-labeling experiments were identical to catalytic activity tests, except H2O was replaced by H2 18O (98% atom 18O, Adamas). The composition of the reaction products was detected by online mass spectroscopy (Hiden analytical HPR20 EGA). The temperature was kept at 200 °C, and m/z = 44(C16O2), m/z = 46(C18O16O), m/z = 48(C18O2), and m/z = 18(H2 16O) were recorded. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 XRD patterns, TEM images, and N2 adsorption characterization Fig. 1 A shows the XRD patterns of Pt/CZOe and Pt/CZO. Both Pt/CZOe and Pt/CZO possess a cubic fluorite structure. The diffraction peaks of Pt/CZOe are significantly broader, indicating lower crystallinity and smaller crystallite size of Pt/CZOe. The crystallite sizes calculated by the Scherrer equation using (111) peaks of Pt/CZOe and Pt/CZO are 5.8 nm and 8.0 nm, respectively. However, the diffraction peak intensity of Pt/CZOe is higher, with some shoulder features at the larger 2θ values side of (220), (311), and (400) peaks (marked by black arrows in Fig. 1A). These features demonstrate the formation of additional Zr-rich crystalline phase, most probably, Ce0.5Zr0.5O2 (PDF#38–1436). Furthermore, the refined XRD patterns of Pt/CZOe and Pt/CZO shown in Fig. S1 indicate the Ce0.75Zr0.25O2 (PDF#28–0271) phase predominates in both CZOe (75.10 %) and CZO (84.22 %) carriers. On the other hand, the XRD patterns of Pt/CZOe and Pt/CZO do not display diffraction peaks of Pt (PDF #04-0802). As a slow scanning rate (2°/min) and a small scan step (0.02) were used in our study, we believe that the Pt atoms on the surface of Pt/CZOe and Pt/CZO are well-dispersed and not in the form of large Pt nanoparticles [8,12,13]. TEM observation was conducted to determine the morphology of Pt/CZOe and Pt/CZO, as shown in Fig. S2. Both Pt/CZOe and Pt/CZO are composited by polyhedral nanoparticles. The average particle size of Pt/CZOe is 7.2 nm, which is significantly smaller than the 13.7 nm of Pt/CZO (Table S2). Pt/CZOe is well dispersed with sufficient stacking pores in a wide range of size, whereas the morphology of Pt/CZO is dense agglomerations, indicating higher BET surface area, higher pore volume, and larger pore size of Pt/CZOe. Fig. 1B-C shows the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of Pt/CZOe and Pt/CZO. Pt/CZO displays type IV isotherms and H2(b) hysteresis loops, indicating the pore blocking of the mesoporous structure of Pt/CZO [14]. Pt/CZOe displays a combination of type II and type IV isotherms with H1 hysteresis loops. The unlimited adsorption at P/P0 = 1.0 indicates the presence of unfilled macropores, and the narrow loop at P/P0 = 0.8–1.0 suggests the capillary condensation which originated from the mesopore network [14–16]. The pore size distribution (Fig. 1D) shows Pt/CZO possesses mesopores inter particulate pores in the range of 2–10 nm. However, Pt/CZOe has a much wider pore size distribution, with the presence of both mesopores and macropores, in agreement with TEM observation. As shown in Table S2, Pt/CZOe has a higher BET surface area (122 m2/g) and remarkably higher pore volume (0.80 cm3/g), such features reflect the superiority of the novel ammonium carbonate etching method. 3.2 Aberration-corrected HAADF-STEM characterization The aberration-corrected HAADF-STEM images of Pt/CZOe and Pt/CZO were conducted to determine the form of Pt species. Pt single atoms can be identified by higher brightness in the dark field, as Pt has a larger atomic number (Z = 78) compared to Ce (Z = 58) and Zr (Z = 40). As shown in Fig. 2 and Fig S2, only individual Pt single atoms were observed on Pt/CZOe and Pt/CZO surfaces (highlighted by white circles in Fig. 2), and no Pt nanoclusters were observed. EDS mapping results (Fig. S4) also showed that Pt atoms were uniformly dispersed on both catalysts, without the existence of Pt agglomeration [17]. 3.3 XPS spectra analysis Fig. 3 shows the XPS spectra of the Pt 4f orbital region and the Ce 3d orbital region for Pt/CZOe and Pt/CZO. As shown in Fig. 3A, the Pt oxidation state of Pt/CZOe and Pt/CZO is predominantly +2, with only a small amount of Pt4+ species, which is consistent with the valence of monoatomic Pt on the CeO2 support [13,18,19]. In addition, the surface Pt content of Pt/CZOe is 0.5 %, much lower than that of Pt/CZO (1.1 %) (Table S1). However, H2-TPR results (Fig. S5) showed that both samples exhibited reduction peaks at 192 °C and 344 °C, which were assigned to the reduction of Pt-O-Ce structure and the reduction of Ce4+ in the vicinity of Pt single atoms, respectively [20]. The Pt-O-Ce peak of Pt/CZOe was slightly weaker but broader compared to that of Pt/CZO, indicating close Pt-O-Ce amounts of Pt/CZOe and Pt/CZO. To further determine the location of Pt atoms in Pt/CZOe, we calcined Pt/CZOe at 800 °C in the air for 10 h to destroy the pore structure. After high-temperature calcination, the surface Pt content of Pt/CZOe increased to 0.8 %. The enhancement of surface Pt content demonstrated that a large amount of Pt was deposited in the pores of Pt/CZOe, which was beyond the detected range of XPS measurement. The XPS spectra of the Ce 3d orbital region for Pt/CZOe and Pt/CZO were shown in Fig. 3B, and the content of Ce3+ is obtained by taking the ratio of the peak areas of Ce3+ and (Ce3+ + Ce4+): C e 3 + = v 0 + v ′ + u 0 + u ′ ∑ i ( v i + u i ) Peaks of Ce 3d orbitals including Ce3+: v0 (880.1 eV), v′ (884.4 eV), u0 (898.4 eV), and u′ (902.8 eV); Ce4+: v (882.0 eV), v″ (888.4 eV), v‴ (898.0 eV), u (900.5 eV), u″ (907.0 eV), and u‴ (916.2 eV) [21]. Comparable high Ce3+ content (∼34 %) was found for both Pt/CZOe and Pt/CZO, which was favorable for potential application. 3.4 CO DRIFTS spectra The Pt species on the surface of Pt/CZOe and Pt/CZO were characterized by CO DRIFTS, and the results are shown in Fig. 4 . Both Pt/CZOe and Pt/CZO exhibit only one band in the 1850–2300 cm−1 region, located at 2096 cm−1. This band is assigned to the linear adsorption of CO molecules on Pt single atoms [13,22-24]. The intensity of the CO-Pt1 band of Pt/CZO is higher than Pt/CZOe. Higher band intensity usually indicates stronger adsorption of CO on Pt species, but in our study, the higher band intensity of Pt/CZO is due to higher surface Pt concentration of Pt/CZO compared to Pt/CZOe (Table S1). There is no band in the low-wavenumber region (1850–2000 cm−1), which corresponds to the bridge bond of CO on Pt nanoparticles. Although the lack of the bridge adsorption cannot be used to demonstrate the atomic-level dispersion of Pt due to its weak adsorption capacity and easy scavenging, it still indicates that Pt atoms are well dispersed on the surface of Pt/CZOe and Pt/CZO [25]. The IR bands at about 2050 cm−1 were also assigned to Pt single atoms, such shoulder features were shown over Pt1/ceria catalysts, where CO adsorbed on low-coordinated Pt1 [13,17,26]. Although Pt nanoclusters also show characteristic bands at about 2050 cm−1, the presence of Pt nanoclusters could be excluded by the results of HAADF-STEM and XPS. As for the features around 2200 cm−1, because no stable bands of CO on Pt species are present in this region, while the CO adsorption on ceria support (2172 cm−1) is weak [27]. Herein, these features should be assigned to the gaseous CO (2174 cm−1) which came from the desorption of CO on Pt1 during the continuous purging of pure Ar. 3.5 Raman spectra Fig. 5 shows the Raman spectra of Pt/CZOe and Pt/CZO. The band at 463 cm−1 was assigned to triply degenerate Ce-O stretching mode with F2G symmetric of cubic fluorite CeO2 lattice [28]. Higher intensity and narrower width of the F2G band of Pt/CZO can be observed, which is owing to larger grain size, in agreement with XRD and TEM results [29,30]. Both Pt/CZOe and Pt/CZO show characteristic bands at 565 cm−1 and 650 cm−1, which are assigned to the vibration of the bridged Pt-O-Ce structure (565 cm−1), and the vibration of the Pt-O-(Ce) structure (650 cm−1), respectively [19,31,32]. This indicates that Pt atoms are anchored by oxygen atoms on the surface of the ceria-zirconia solid solutions to form Pt-O-Ce structures. 3.6 CO oxidation activity In order to investigate the impact of water vapor on reaction activity, we conducted experiments by comparing the CO oxidation activity of Pt/CZOe and Pt/CZO in dry and wet conditions, as illustrated in Fig. 6 . Under dry conditions, Pt/CZOe and Pt/CZO exhibited comparable activity, showing barely any activity below 120 °C and achieving 100 % conversion of CO at 190 °C. However, upon introducing 2.5 kPa of water vapor into the reaction atmosphere, the activity of both Pt/CZO and Pt/CZO increased. This was mainly observed with Pt/CZOe, whose T10, T50, and T100(temperatures achieved 10 %, 50 %, 100 % conversion) were approximately 65 °C, 110 °C, and 90 °C lower than the dry reaction without water vapor, respectively. The enhancement of CO oxidation activity of catalysts by water vapor has been reported in the Pt/CeO2 (or Pt/CeO2-ZrO2) system [8,33-35]. However, comprehending the role of water molecules in the catalytic process remains a huge challenge [1]. For Pt/CZOe and Pt/CZO, Pt is supported on ceria-zirconia supports (CZOe and CZO) that were prepared by different methods, leading to varying degrees of enhancement in catalytic activity for CO oxidation by water vapor. Determining the origin of this difference can significantly contribute to our comprehensive understanding of the entire catalytic process. 3.7 In-situ CO DRIFTS spectra analysis In-situ CO DRIFTS measurements under wet conditions over Pt/CZOe and Pt/CZO were performed, and the results were shown in Fig. 7 (4000–3300 cm−1, -OH region) and Fig. 8 (2300–1800 cm−1, CO region). The evolution of hydroxyl groups on the surface of Pt/CZOe and Pt/CZO during the reaction can be easily detected through in-situ DRIFTS, as shown in Fig. 7. The assignments of the bands are based on previous reports, as shown in Table S3 [36–40]. After being purged under CO and O2 atmosphere for 15 min, both Pt/CZOe and Pt/CZO displayed negative features, indicating that the hydroxyl groups were consumed by reacting with CO, especially for type I Ce-OH species. After the introduction of H2O, a new v(OH) band at 3695 cm−1 and a new broad v(OH…) band at about 3400 cm−1 were assigned to undissociated H2O molecules [40,41], such features of Pt/CZOe were more obvious compared to that of Pt/CZO. The enhanced band intensity at 3710 cm−1 for Pt/CZOe was also observed, while it remained negative for Pt/CZO. These results demonstrated that Pt/CZOe had a greater capability to adsorb water molecules and dissociate them into type I Ce-OH, which directly participates in the CO oxidation process. This may be the key to Pt/CZOe having better CO oxidation activity under wet conditions. By comparing these two catalysts, porosity is the most prominent difference among the properties of Pt/CZOe and Pt/CZO. The total pore volume of Pt/CZOe is 0.80 cm3/g, and this value is approximately 4 times that of Pt/CZO (0.19 cm3/g) (Table S2). Previous studies had demonstrated that porous ceria was favored in proton conduction under wet conditions compared to dense nanocrystalline ceria [42,43]. In a recent study, Sun et al. pointed out that water adsorption capacity is proportional to the BET surface areas and pore volumes of ceria [44]. Herein, we believe the high pore volume is responsible for the greater capacity to adsorb water vapor of Pt/CZOe. In the 2300–1800 cm−1 region, after 15 min of CO adsorption, Pt/CZOe and Pt/CZO showed a band at 2100 cm−1 and 2096 cm−1, respectively. These bands were assigned to the linear adsorption of CO on isolated Pt2+. The introduction of water vapor to the gas flow decreased the band intensity of CO-Pt2+. This decrease further continued after CO was removed from the gas flow. This might be due to the competitive adsorption of CO and H2O on the Pt2+ site [33]. Besides, the band positions of CO-Pt2+ on Pt/CZOe and Pt/CZO had been red-shifted to 2091 cm−1 and 2092 cm−1, respectively. The change in band position suggests a modification in the local chemical environment of Pt2+ on the catalysts’ surface [26]. In our study, the difference observed may be attributed to the dissociation of H2O on the Ce atom of the Pt-O-Ce structure, leading to the formation of type I Ce-OH, which interacts with Pt-CO. The remaining H atom combines with the O adjacent to Pt, resulting in a local chemical environment change of Pt2+. Furthermore, the presence of water vapor broadens the band of CO-Pt2+, providing additional evidence that the local chemical environment of Pt is more widely distributed. 3.8 18O isotope labeling experiments With the help of mass spectroscopy, the oxygen source of the CO oxidation can be determined by using 18O labeled heavy-oxygen water (H2 18O) [8,45]. Herein, the time-resolved H2 18O isotope labeling experiment on Pt/CZOe was performed, and the results were shown in Fig. 9 . Considering the H2 16O impurity in the H2 18O, the background spectrum of H2 16O was recorded and removed. The formation of C18O2 and C18O16O with a ratio of approximately 2:1 can be observed after the introduction of CO and O2, and only a minimal amount of C16O2 was observed. The formation of H2 16O was also observed during the reaction, and its content was close to C18O2. This shows that H2 18O acts as a reactant in the reaction process, enhancing the CO oxidation rate significantly more than the normal MvK process under dry conditions. To investigate the formation mechanism of C18O2 and C18O16O, H2 18O labeled in-situ CO DRIFTS experiment of Pt/CZOe was performed, and the results were shown in Fig. 10 . After introducing H2 18O into the gas flow, surprisingly, the band intensity of CO-Pt2+ at 2100 cm-1 decreased significantly while a new band appeared at 2048 cm−1. The new band was not assigned to Pt nanoparticles since this feature was not found during the H2 16O-involved in-situ CO DRIFTS experiment (Fig .8A). According to the harmonic oscillator model, the vibration frequency of diatomic molecules is related to their reduced mass by the −1/2 power law [46]. When the oxygen atom of C16O is replaced with 18O, the ratio of the reduced mass of C18O to the reduced mass of C16O μ(C16O): μ(C18O) = 1.05. Therefore, the ratio of vibration frequencies of C18O and C16O is v(C18O): v(C16O) = (1/1.05) 0.5 = 0.976, while 2048/2100 = 0.975, the two values are quite close. Herein, the new band at 2048 cm−1 is assigned to the linear adsorption of C18O on Pt2+. The band intensity of C18O-Pt2+ is significantly higher than that of C16O-Pt2+, which corresponds well to the formation of only a small amount of C16O2 in Fig. 9. The formation of C18O-Pt2+ means that after introducing H2 18O, the C16O molecules adsorbed on Pt undergo cleavage, and 16O is replaced by 18O in H2 18O. 4 Conclusion In summary, we used CeO2-ZrO2 prepared by the ammonium carbonate etching method (CZOe) and co-precipitation method (CZO) as supports, synthesized Pt/CZOe and Pt/CZO catalysts. The XRD, HAADF-STEM, XPS, DRIFTS, and Raman results revealed that Pt species were uniformly dispersed on the surface of the catalysts as Pt2+ single sites. Pt/CZOe and Pt/CZO had similar CO oxidation activities under dry conditions, but both Pt/CZOe and Pt/CZO catalysts were activated when 2.5 kPa steam was introduced into the reaction gas, especially the T100 of Pt/CZOe decreased by 100 °C. Benefiting from wider pore size distribution and larger pore volume, Pt/CZOe has a stronger ability to adsorb water molecules and dissociate them into type I Ce-OH, and showed a remarkable enhancement of low-temperature CO oxidation activity under wet conditions compared to Pt/CZO. The 18O isotope labeling experiments demonstrated that water directly participated in the reaction process as a reactant rather than simply changing the adsorption behavior of CO, the CO bond of CO molecules adsorbed on Pt will be broken and replaced by hydroxyl oxygen of adjacent Ce-OH in the presence of steam. coredata.dc:description: CO oxidation reaction has important industrial significance in controlling automotive exhaust emissions, however, the effect of steam on the activity of ceria-zirconia solid solutions supported catalyst is still unclear. In this study, ceria-zirconia solid solutions were prepared by the traditional co-precipitation method (CZO) and the novel ammonium carbonate etching method (CZOe). After loading 1 wt% Pt, the synthesized Pt/CZOe and Pt/CZO catalysts were characterized comprehensively by XRD, HAADF-STEM, XPS, DRIFTS, and Raman spectroscopy, the results suggested that the Pt species were uniformly dispersed as Pt2+ single sites. Both Pt/CZOe and Pt/CZO catalysts could be activated under wet conditions and showed improved CO oxidation activity compared to dry conditions, especially the CO complete conversion temperature (T100) of Pt/CZOe decreased by 100 °C. Furthermore, the enhancement mechanism of steam on the catalysts has been deeply studied using in-situ CO DRIFTS spectra analysis and 18O isotope labeling experiments, which indicated that H2O molecules were adsorbed and dissociated on the surface of the catalysts, forming terminal Ce-OH bonds that facilitated the reaction rate. The Pt/CZOe catalyst showed a remarkable enhancement of low-temperature CO oxidation activity under wet conditions compared to the Pt/CZO catalyst due to the outstanding porosity which facilitates the adsorption of H2O molecules. In the H2 18O-involved experiments, the formation of C18O2 and C18O16O and the appearance of the C18O-Pt2+ band demonstrated that H2O molecules participated in the reaction directly as reactants, the CO bond of CO molecules adsorbed on Pt could be broken and replaced by hydroxyl oxygen of adjacent Ce-OH. The present work revealed the enhancement effect and mechanism of steam on the CO oxidation performance of ceria-zirconia solid solutions supported catalyst, and the research methods and results in this work have important reference significance for the activation research of other catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Steam activation significantly promotes the CO oxidation performance of Pt/CeZrO2 catalyst: Enhancement effect and mechanism
